description: When an emergency vehicle is detected within 200 meters of an intersection and queues are long, extend the green phase on its approach and shorten conflicting phases for 3 cycles.
When an emergency vehicle is approaching with moderate congestion, extend green time on the main approach for 2 cycles while maintaining minimum service for side streets.
Under low congestion, give normal green but avoid unnecessary stops for approaching emergency vehicles by reducing red time when possible.
If average speed on a segment drops below 10 km/h and density is high, increase green time for the congested approach by 20 seconds for the next 3 cycles.
If average speed is between 10 and 25 km/h with medium queues, slightly increase green time for the main movement and monitor for improvement.
If a road segment is fully blocked due to an incident, set signal plans to prevent vehicles from entering the blocked segment and direct them to predefined detour routes.
If one lane is blocked but others are open, reduce green time for the affected approach and encourage diversion through alternate corridors.
During school start and end times, increase pedestrian crossing time and reduce green time for through traffic near schools to protect vulnerable users.
During low demand night hours, switch to vehicle-actuated control and flashing mode when no vehicles are detected for a configurable period.
During heavy rain or flooding alerts, reduce maximum permitted speed and extend amber and all-red phases to account for longer braking distances.
Around stadiums or event venues, before and after events, modify signal timings to prioritize exit routes and public transport corridors.
When work zones are active, update signal phases to remove closed lanes and rebalance timings for remaining movements to avoid spillback.
